social_posts.post_text:
#artvsartist 💫 my 1st drawing was at four - the kindergarten class drew our country’s flag but mine looked like a wonky letter B. after seeing classmates drawings (PS: as a kid i had very high IQ & a competitive streak lol), i wanted to draw better and started to draw on everything - papers, books, the walls. 

a year later : won my first drawing competition at school - a drawing of people cleaning up the neighbourhood. what the drawing lacks in imaginative subject matter, it makes up in technical achievement. meaning: the people look like people. no more of that wonky letter B for me. and the rest is…a story.

many years & trophies later, drawing remains a casual hobby for me. something to do. until one day in highschool.

saw the cover of a poetry book in the library. a painting of a woman sitting in a quiet restaurant. the fine print said the painting is Automat by Edward Hopper. i riffled through the encyclopaedia at home to find H, Hopper. all the famous paintings i’ve seen thus far were of flowers, landscape, historic figures. so fascinating to read about painter who’s known to paint about “urban isolation” and the feeling of loneliness. 

i started to read so much about art & the stories of artists. i never formally study art or become a full time artist. but it has become such a big part of who i am today. learning & making art enable me to connect with my “human”-ness and others’. it teaches me to find beauty even in the most mundane. to listen and try to understand different perspectives. it also teaches me that despite our differences, we are all connected in this shared experience of being human. that we are not as alone as we think™️

art is about so much more than likeness, style, techniques, aesthetics. 

art is a story about being human. maybe it’s one of the few things that “made” us human, in a day & age when you - a human - have to convince a robot that you’re not a robot (read: captcha).

any art made by human is better than what an AI can churn out. because art is about stories, and each of us has a story (or a million) worth telling. to all artsy souls reading this: keep telling your story. keep making the art that only you can make ❤️💙
updated version of my First Day At The Office photo. time flies by when time flies by. and 2022 is drawing to an end. what a year of DISCOvery ❤️💙💫

film shots from Mexico City trip 🇲🇽 #choonica35mm is back after long hiatus lol. really love the vibe of CDMX the city of so many museums and gorgeous building facades. but my ultimate favorite is the streetside snack stalls 💫
fav film shots from mexico city trip #choonica35mm 🇲🇽❤️💙 the museums, oh all the museums. and the streetside snack stalls.

so happy that i get to visit Toeti Heraty Museum while i’m in town. The museum is the former residence of bu Toeti Heraty - poet, professor, art collector. Beside the exhibition halls, visitors can also walk around and see the family’s Music Room, Library, and even the living quarters. i’ve always wondered what the inside of Menteng mansions look like, so that’s a bonus on top of the impressive private art collection. 
Sharing my faves below and here’s to learning more abt 🇮🇩 art and history 💫

1. “Toeti, Migni dan Cyril” - S. Sudjojono, 1971. a portrait by bu Toeti, the owner of this residence + art collection, with her children - painted by the founder of Indonesian modern art and my fav Indonesian artist of all thyme. 
2. “Raden Saleh” - Srihadi Soedarsono, 1971. Raden Saleh seems to be an inevitably looming figure over Indonesian art. have mixed feelings about this (another essay for another time!) but i definitely Soedarsono’s modernist take on the portrait. 
3. “Waiting in The Lobby” - Kartika Affandi, 1974. The artist is a close friend of bu Toeti, and there’s a note about how they became friends in the 1960s and they even have the same birthday. This painting was part of Kartika Affandi’s all black & white exhibition in which she sold zero painting. But after her father, the Indonesian maestro Affandi, passed away - her paintings rose to stratospheric price and bu Toeti almost gave up the hope to ever own her friend’s painting.
4. “Standing Reception” - Otto Djaja, 1982. The naïveté and vibrant colors remind me Matisse. Social criticism is often a theme in Otto Djaja’s work.
5. “Expecting Mother” - Roelijati, 1961. so excited to learn about female Indonesian artist in my fav era (the 60s). 
6. no info abt the painting but i like it!
7. “Landscape” - Trisno Soemardjo. the artist is the first chairman of Dewan Kesenian Jakarta, and together with S. Sudjojono they are the first proponents of Indonesian art critic.
8. Photograph of (L-R): Mochtar Apin, Chairil Anwar, Asrul Sani, Baharuddin Marasutan. the founding members of Gelanggang - Indonesian young artists organization in 1946 - just one year after our independence.
first time in seoul and surely it’s a memorable one 🍂💙❤️ 🖼️ #Choonica35mm
fav shots from #choonica35mm seoul roll. it is what it is (but what is it)

“What is art? To answer this is very difficult. If an artist makes an art object, then actually the fruit of the art itself is nothing but his own visible soul. Art is a visible soul. Thus, art is the soul. 

New paintings do not propagate beauty, but propagate the truth to everyone” - S. Sudjojono

when you visit a new country, you’d get a grasp of the country & the nation’s “soul” through various interfaces - through how the people talk (lively or soft spoken?) when they greet you,  through how the food taste (bold or subtle?) when you try the local dish, through how they prefer their coffee (sweetened or bitter?) at the neighbourhood coffee shops, through how the street sounds (bustling or quiet?) when you go around the city, through the news and shows you see on the local tv, through what kind of local celebs that’s deemed to be worthy of adoration or insults on social media, through what topics the taxi driver use to strike up a conversation with you, etc. These different interfaces might not feel immediately cohesive - but it gives you more facets of the same “soul”. 

being an Indonesian and having lived in Indonesia for most of my lyfe, i was surprised and in turn delighted to see another facet of our collective identity as a nation - through the paintings that graced the walls of the national gallery. i found some of them beautiful, some grotesque. some truthful, some deceitful (re: Mooi Indie). but all of them “whisper” the same sentences: this is who we were, this is who we are, and most poignantly..this is who we could’ve been. 

1. “Rose Pandanwangi Istriku” / Rose Pandanwangi My Wife - S. Sudjojono, 1959
2. “Istriku (Ibu Menjahit)” / My Wife (Mother Sewing) - S. Sudjojono, 1944
3. “Ibuku” / My Mother - S. Sudjojono, 1938
4. “Minta Sumbangan Gedung” (Asking for Donation) - Tatang Ganar, 1965
5. “Ibu” (Mother) - Affandi, 1941
6. “Tiga Gadis Minahasa” (Three Minahasan Girls) - Henk Ngantung, 1949
7. “Mbah Irosentono” - Trubus Soedarsono, 1960
8. “Telaga Warna” - Abdullah Soerjo Soebroto, 1932
henri, claude, et pablo. #Choonica35mm

fav from the #Choonica36mm Tokyo film roll. all of the scans from this roll has a yellowish & hazy overlay - not sure if it’s because of the lowlight inside the museum (my camera Konika Genba Kantoku is primarily an outdoor camera) or because i didn’t wipe the lens on that particularly cold & humid day (it was raining in tokyo). either way - i really like the mood on this roll. here’s hoping for more museum visits in 2023 🌎

“Art should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable.” - or so goes the famous saying. this phrase came to mind when visiting Chiharu Shiota’s exhibition “The Soul Tremble” at @museummacan . her work reminds me of three artist: Yayoi Kusama’s repetitive (compulsive?) pattern and concept of space, Marina Abramovic’s graphic & visceral (often grotesque) exploration on pain and the body, and Stanley Kubrick’s suspenseful perfectionism & stories about underlying deep-seated trauma that bubbles up to the surface. apparently Chiharu Shiota indeed was a protege to Abramovic, and her earlier works were performance art and she then evolved into large scale installation. Thread especially in red and black color is used in most of her installation - and it often symbolizes complexity of human relations. A lot of the artist / curatorial notes are centered on the topic of childhood, family, Japanese culture, and experience as immigrants. In my opinion, modern art puts bigger emphasis on context or sometimes the context itself is the “art” - but i really enjoyed reading the notes and trying to connect the dots between the story and the artwork itself. 
.
coming back to the quote in the beginning - it’s indeed subjective what we find comforting and what we find disturbing. perhaps there’s a certain comfort in putting the amorphous & invisible psychological experiences into physical forms that you can grasp and therefore put forward - or maybe put behind.

my hope for 2023 to know better on when to do which.
.
because time and energy are finite - spend them to pursue what matters
because people are put in each other’s path to help each other grow in a particular chapter of lyfe - and when the chapter is over, we’re still on our own path to grow
because little details like an apostrophe makes a big difference, and so do little things like the seconds we pause to think before responding, the thank you’s we say to people who hold the elevator door open, the little Heart that we tapped on a friend’s drawing, and what we choose to pick up (or to put down) in the morning when we just woke up, etc.
because baggage can be necessary - but only when we choose to carry what we need in the journey forward.
because most things have a function, but not everything has a purpose. 
.
here’s to a new year growing in knowledge - but also in wisdom, friends.
last film roll from my Bali trip back in August 2022. posting this in January 2023 because…mentally am always here. #Choonica35mm
2022 was lyfe changing. gratitude and hope for 2023

the cloud sunset bears : 5 years apart. painted the gouache version (the one on the bottom) on the last days of 2022 and first day of 2023, while the crayon version was drawn during a flight back in 2017. 
.
feels good to be back at painting and am hoping to restart my illustration sketchbooks and habit in 2023. last year was lyfe changing (every year is, tbh - in its own unique way) in that it was a transitional year - i barely made any painting and did very few drawings for Choo Choo compared to 5 years ago. 
.
but then again - everything else in lyfe has also changed so much and i can say that i’m more at peace with the 2023 version of myself - but only because the 2017 version of myself has gone through what she needed to go through. it’s the same for these two versions of this sketchbook, it’s not about which one is better - progression is about growing through what you’re going through 💫
out and about in the city. got some of my fave albums on vinyl, saw some art that i like (and some i don’t care much for lol). singapore feels particularly vibrant during the Art Week ❤️💙

highlights from ART SG. am not the biggest fan of big art expo (prefer gallery/museum exhibitions as you can learn a bit more about the story behind the art) but it’s always good to expose our ~palate to new ranges. i really gravitate towards artworks that look a bit naive and ‘quiet’ - and the color blue haha. not much psychoanalysis needed there. 
.
also: spotted a Miro from a mile away (not literally lah).
.

1. Schwan - Bin Woo Hyuk, 2021
2. This Way - Jim Lutes, 2011
3. Torso, Ruin of The Four Noble Truth - Natee Utarit, 2022
4. Personage, Renaud - Joan Miro, 1970-1971
5. Maske CXII - Jonathan Baldock, 2022
6. Flood In The Garden - Marcel Dzarma, 2022
7. Stardust - James Prapaithong, 2022
8. A Good Idea - Abdul Abdullah, 2022
9. (couldn’t find the artist’s details)

#Biblichootheque is back with the latest @sorryimbookedreads selection. 

many books have been written about what the internet does (or can do) to us as a society, a generation, or even as a species. my fave is Infinite Jest written by the brilliant David Foster Wallace back in 1996. He didn’t exactly write about the internet - instead: “The Entertainment” - a film so entertaining that upon being exposed to its opening scene, its viewers won’t be able to divert their attention from the Entertainment. After they see the film, and then want nothing more than to watch it repeatedly, the “victims” are consigned to psychiatric wards. The persons’ lives’ meanings had collapsed to such a narrow focus that no other activity or connection could hold their attention. Extreme as it may sound, it’s hard to deny that us human-beings have a yearning to the point addiction of being constantly entertained and instantly gratified - and the internet (with its “feed” and seemingly endless scroll-ability) is such an enticing and easy way to be entertained and gratified that we gloss over the less-interesting question: but at what cost?

Fast forward to almost 30 years later: the internet became such an integral part of our lyfe as individuals, society, etc etc and Patricia Lockwood writes about the same question in this immensely entertaining book. On one side, Lockwood uses her knack for writing the punchiest & wittiest one liners and random-yet- astutely intriguing questions show us one thing : the internet permeates our collective vocabulary  and with every viral tweet and clickbait headline,  we’re inching closer to speak one common language: The Internet Language.

On the other hand, while memes become the shorthand (or replacement?) of communicating and relating to each other, the book also shows us another thing: we are increasingly detached, disconnected, and desensitised to a lot of things. When news about tragedy is a scroll away from cute cat videos, maybe it doesn’t take much imagination to ponder on the implication. But what this book does is to take that implication to an extreme, and in its way - it makes readers laugh, cringe, gasp, and hopefully realize something.

Living Pictures : Photography in South East Asia. such an illuminating exhibition as it casts light on the role of photography in this region throughout the centuries. In the 19th century, photography arrived with the European colonist who produced beautiful - but often racist and ignorant - images, circulated in books and postcard. In a very practical sense, photography regulated the vision of SEA in the this period. Then, South East Asian people - especially the ruling elites - saw the power of photography to influence perception. It quickly become a way of seeing and imagining oneself. As photography become more accessible in the early 20th century, it chronicles the life of the people, even the working class. And the ones that brought me goosebumps: photos that captured resistance of people against oppression and imperialism. It’s my first time seeing those photographs of Soekarno and Hatta each giving a speech, surrounded by people - less than 5 years after Indonesian independence. it feels like a full circle moment. as a medium, photography always feels more factual - but there’s always a narrative, a story, and a perspective. the question is: whose is it?
.

1. Jakarta, 8 June 1947. Vice President Mohammad Hatta stopping by the Manggarai Station while en route to Sumatra from Yogyakarta.
2. Jakarta, 28 December 1949. President Soekarno gave a speech at the Istana Merdeka upon his return to Jakarta from Yogyakarta, where he has been since 2 January 1946
3. Chinese Workmen at Tiffin, c. 1900 by G.R Lambert & Co. (Singapore)
4. Native Portable Kitchen, West Java, c. 1912-1919 by Kleynenberg & Co. (the Dutch Indies)
5. Hamengkubuwono VI, Sultan of Jogjakarta & Ratu Kencana, Principal Consort of Hamengkubuwono VI, c. 1858 by Woodbury & Page (the Dutch Indies)
6. Rama V with Children, 1890s. Photographer unknown (Thailand)
7. Rama / Bridge, c. 1958 by Rong Wong-Savun (Thailand)
8. Laundry - 1940 by Yip Cheong Fun
9. Mobile Military Medical Clinic during the Period when the Enemy is Defoliating U Minh Forest - c. 1970 by Vo An Kanh (Vietnam)

opening weekend of Liu Kuo Sung: Experimentation as Method exhibition and it was out of this world - pun intended 🌙  Lio Kuo Sung (born 1932) is an artist that plays a big role in the modernisation of Chinese ink painting. He pushes the boundaries of existing methods in traditional Chinese ink painting in pursuit of new techniques and expressions. The exhibition showcases his work spanning across more than 5 decades, but what i absolutely love is his Space series created in the late 1960s to early 70s. To me this series is brilliant because it achieves the amazing feat of perfectly capturing the era in which it was created (hashtag ✨zeitgeist ✨) in its subject matter while being completely ahead of its time in style and vision. In the 60s, the world indeed was indeed captivated in The Space Race (and - uhm - the Cold War) culminating in Apollo 11 and moon landing in 1969. Throughout the decade, the imagery of space & moon permeated the media, pop culture (Kubrick’s masterpiece 2001: A Space Odyssey) and evidently in Lio Kuo Sung’s works: the world of fine art is not beyond the last frontier. While the images on TV and magazines focused on showing the details and textures of the moon, earth, and sun, Liu treated the circle-dominated pictorial surface as flat, normalized and reductive. Combined with the expressive brush strokes, it creates an intriguing visual contrast. And let’s be real: the crisp lines, subtle gradient, and the (for the lack of better words) graphic designey composition - can you believe this is created by hands?? in the 60s?? 🌗 i really enjoyed poring over the Space paintings and learning about the new-to-me artist. If you’re in SG, definitely do check out the exhibition 🌙🪐 to the moon!

saturday well-spent 💙💫 learning about cyanotype and the act of “giving control to randomness”. have been seeing a lot of cyanotype artwork recently and been wanting to learn about this unconventional printing techniques - using the power of chemistry, light, time, and ✨probability ✨. 
.
initially wanted to make artwork with the gingko leaves i brought from Tokyo but forgot where i stored them lol. pivoted into making a @real_choochoo cutout and see where it goes. combined with the ferns and wild vines i found next to the studio building, resulting in Choo Choo getting Lost In The Woods 🌳 am really fascinated by the process as well as the result - and thinking to layer it with line drawing, watercolor, or maybe a red natural dye ? 💫 endless probability. 
.
everyone’s cyanotype in the workshop looks so unique and beautiful. here’s to making art that only you can make™️
.
thanks @knucklesandnotch and @chowcalvinchow for this enlightening workshop!

january. you of colorful clouds amidst dreary drizzle. of fireworks and wild ferns. of records playing in another room, from another time. of written hopes and unspoken wishes. of beginnings, new or otherwise. of making it count, making it through, making it. 
.
january, you are something else.

selected paintings from Gaze and Gloss (2019) and The Hong Lim Series: Line and Fragments (2022) by Jon Chan. The theme of estrangement, displacement, and alienation are woven into these paintings - there’s sense of unsentimental detachment to the subject matters (one of the paintings are titled “Oddballs Event”) but at the same time I feel the people in the paintings are portrayed in an empathetic light. and of course - the visible brushstrokes, vibrant colors, the dancing lights, subdued atmosphere - it reminds me of impressionism and that’s always good👌🏻
february. blue sky but it’s grey outside. grey clouds and it’s blue inside. there’s something to be said about dressing for the weather : never. we are what we’re willing to make peace with.

Take Your Time - third solo exhibition by Thai artist Suntur. saw photos of the exhibition a while ago and really glad i got to actually visit it in Bangkok. 
.
the paintings displayed in this exhibition are in the same vein - a surreal landscape with either a minuscule solitary figure or a couple in the middle. the composition tells a story and the title of each painting sum it up in an almost platitude-esque way. there’s a feeling of unabashed, sincere vulnerability which one would rarely find in contemporary art these days (feel like everyone is busy being meta and Making A Statement™️ to me). it’s sentimental, but just the right amount before it becomes a platitude. 
.
my faves:
1-3 i found happiness in sadness
4-5 things come when it’s time
6 happiness won’t last long
7 dream is sweet so i’ll snooze
8 take your time
9 lost and found
10 found and lost

let’s gogh 💙🌻 there was a saying that no one has ever seen a cypress tree until Vincent Van Gogh painted it. truly an iconoclast that changed how the world see colors and nature. seeing his work together with the narration about his life also reminded me of another saying - true sorrow is connected to true beauty.

“...and then, I have nature and art and poetry, and if that is not enough, what is enough?”
.
Vincent Van Gogh is clearly one of the most celebrated artists in the modern times - on a History of Art 101 pantheon he shared with Pablo Picasso, Claude Monet, Salvador Dali, and Frida Kahlo. like the other four, Van Gogh is an iconoclast that changes how people see colors, nature, beauty, and life itself. however unlike the other four, Van Gogh was the only one who did not enjoy success & fame during his lifetime. the story surrounding his life and the tragic end is well-known and sometimes i wonder if we probably are so captivated by the Van Gogh-ism that we reduced this great artist to a quote unquote celebrity. 
.
seeing his artwork in this immersive exhibitions reminds me that first and foremost he’s a human being that grapples with sadness & loss, that longs for beauty despite finding it everywhere, whose prolificness is not an anthesis of his struggle - instead : an evidence of it. seeing all the vibrant colors and spirited brushstrokes in a larger-than-life scale, it reminded me as well that maybe beauty and sorrow are interconnected closer than we’d like to think.

seoul day 1 🌸 strolling around @dialimm_ ‘s lovely neighbourhood, a trip to the museum for the moon jar (and students on school trip starting convos with me to practice english - so cute), and incredibly good food.

seoul day 2 - which was supposed to be day 1. moved my flight one day earlier and was a bit hesitant about it last week. turns out the weather was perfect yesterday - gave me a chance to see the flowers in bloom before the all-day rain washed away most of them today. alas - lost and found. everything happens for a reason. 
.
changed some plans, bought some records, saw some joseon porcelains, ate some good soup (lol). seeing the bright side of a rainy day.

seoul day 3.1 - is it just me or the weather’s getting Calder.
.
Lee Jung Seop at MMCA seoul, Lee Ufan & Alexander Calder at Kukje gallery. form and shape - and stories 💙❤️💛
seoul day 3.2 - wandered into the mountains for a taste of the Belle Epoque. Monet painted blurry waterlilies because of cataract and Picasso took care of a wounded owl. the more you know.

seoul day 4.1 - met an old friend i haven’t ‘seen’ in some time. felt like an apology is overdue but i couldn’t come up with a good reason - maybe i should give it more time.
.
thank choo @dialimm_ for recommending this place ✨

seoul day 4.2 or “7-IV-2023” as kim whanki would write as title of his paintings. his paintings are mostly in large scale (up to 3m in height) with meticulous concentric patterns. each painting must’ve taken weeks or months to complete - and each day leading up to the titular date. got me thinking that maybe closures are made, not given.
.

this day is one for the books.
seoul day 5. this barbie needs stop going to unplanned mountain hikes. nature, art, music, and pancake made of meat.

“blue plays a greater role for me. from the sky’s light blue to the night’s dark blue. the color of the mind and dreams.” - Andre Brasilier
.
seoul day 6. met some twins at Andre Brasilier and Heesoo Kim exhibition. warm iced coffee. and “sunset by the river” always has a nice ring to it.
seoul day 7. out and about - indeed.

day 8 - a grey gloomy day saved by hotteok. day 9 - couldn’t ask for a better day to close this trip. vacation is special because it ends, travel is special because you return. grateful for every day.
spring in seoul. one for the books. thank you, thank you.
ready, march, go. art that i saw and didn’t in march. time flies no matter what kind of time you’re having. so might as well etc.
for the record: a long weekend. take it slow, or just take it.
april TLDR (too lovely, didn’t regret).

On Museums, the Paradox of Change, and Why Art Moves Me (Us?) to Tears.

Many years ago I visited Tokyo for the first time with a group of friends - mainly to go to a music festival (and see Radiohead!) and visit amusement parks (where i stared at multiple rollercoasters). On the last day of the trip, we split up for solo activities and I went to two museums in Ueno Park. First museum is National Museum of Natural Science - and the magnificent display of whale and dinosaur there reminded me of a passage in Catcher in the Rye, when Holden visited The Museum of Natural History in New York and lamented about how the displays in the museum will remain the same, but every time he visits it - he will be different. In a coming of age book about loss of innocence, the museum symbolises preservation and how futile it can be.

The next museum was National Museum of Western Art - where I saw one of Monet’s Waterlilies for the first time. It was a weekday afternoon and there was a Japanese grandpa with pink shirt who stood in front of me - we both admired the painting and he took out his flip phone to capture the painting while i whipped out my iPhone. I remembered thinking how anachronistic his phone looked, before I realized the painting itself is an anachronism. It has survived multiple evolutions in phone camera resolution - it was created even before telephone exists. It has ‘seen’ generations of visitors marvelled and moved to tears in front of it, museums built and torn down, cities evolved and sprawled, rulers of nations reigned and fell - it has seen many beginnings and ends, many lives and many deaths. And the lilies remain floating and frozen in moment: a bright afternoon in Giverny, more than 200 years ago. As a fledging illustrator at that time, I remember thinking maybe this is what art is about. To connect people from continents and centuries apart - to sit still and take it in - beauty, time, changes, life, and what comes after & before. 

(Continued in comment)

#Michoolin SEOUL part 1 - the post you all (me and, like, two other people) have been waiting for is here! List of my fav places in Seoul 💙 and of course we will start with museums. TBH am blown away by all the museums & galleries I’ve visited in this city - not only because they are very well-managed and curated, but also because there are always visitors around the day even on weekdays. I really like the idea of finding solace and perhaps a bit of escapism in the quiet presence of art amidst the busy city life. 

1. LeeUm Museum of Art - consists of two parts that house traditional Korean art (permanent collection) and contemporary art (temporary exhibition). My fav is the first part especially the display of Celadon and white Joseon porcelain. I once read that there’s a philosophy in Korean art about “Telling the story by saying as little as possible” - and that there’s beauty in void. I think the curves in moon jar and the muted green hue of celadon ware are perfect example of these. You can find various international contemporary art in the second part of museum - the likes of Maurizio Catellan, Anish Kapoor, Olafur Eliasson, Gerhard Richter, etc. Also, as expected from a museum owned by Samsung, the audio guide system in this museum is really state of the art and it’s free lol. 
2. Whanki Museum - officially my fav museum in Seoul. I’ve seen the paintings on Whanki on printed pages and phone screens, but when I finally see the paintings with my own eyes - only then did I *get* it. Large in scale (almost 3 meter in height) and subdued in their deceivingly-simple pattern, the paintings feel like an enigmatic presence that draws you in. The museum is relatively small but very well-designed with natural lighting, Escher-esque mezzanines, and even the ambiance music feels very personal and cohesive to Kim Whanki’s life and work. I think i spent almost 30 min staring at some of the paintings from the series “Where, in What Form, Shall We Meet Again” - photos are not allowed inside so the interior photo is credit to the museum’s official IG account.

cont’d in comment.

#Michoolin Seoul continues with Galleries & Art Centers - unlike the museums in part 1, these places don’t have permanent collection (i think). Again - i’ll just say there are so much art to see in Seoul - fine art, art that are just fine (hehe), illustration, photography, installation, etc.

Sharing here some of my faves: 
1. Dongdaemun Design Plaza - the iconic building designed by Zaha Hadid Architects  so definitely a must visit on its own. I went there to see the best illustration exhibition ever by my fav illustrator Jean Jullien 
2. Amorepacific Museum of Art (APMA) - went there to see Beyond Folding Screens 2, exhibition of painted wooden partition screen from the Joseon era. . 
3. Seoul Arts Center - went there to see Andre Brasilier Recent Works exhibition, a France /artist that I wasn’t familiar with prior to visiting the exhibition. Turns out I quite enjoyed his colorful & somewhat whimsical paintings.
4. Kukje Gallery - I hit the jackpot - got into Lee Ufan & Alexander Calder exhibition only two days since it opens - without booking a slot (it was fully booked for the next two weeks). First time seeing Calder’s works irl so certainly very grateful. They also have small bookstore with mighty selection of English books about Korean & international contemporary artists. So check it out and try not to buy everything lol. 
5. Everyday Mooonday Gallery - went there to see Heesoo Kim solo exhibition Monologue. It’s a rather small space but they and seem to always showcase work from a diverse range of illustrators from all over the world. 

Most of the exhibitions mentioned here have closed now - so do check out the gallery’s website to find out what temporary exhibition is ongoing.

grew up not really liking my name cause i didn’t think if fits me - until i found out the literal meaning of both words: Chitra (Sanskrit: चित्र) – a picture/painting, and Marinus (Latin) - of the sea. maybe it does fit me.

PSA.. to self.
.
drawings from the vault about the fault of living in my head a lot (too much). i remember thinking as i was drawing that maybe these are too cerebral that they will go over people’s head (pun intended, always) but then i remember that first and foremost that @real_choochoo is a dialogue with my own self ie: tell things that i need to tell myself.

The protagonist in the latest #Biblichootheque book is called An Jin-Jin - her given name means truth, but her last name means no. She’s born into contradictions, surrounded by contradictions. 

Jin Jin’s mother juggled between tending the store she owns, learning law & Japanese through books, and solving the problems caused by her runaway-from-home daughter, noir-gangster-wannabe son, and her deadbeat-violent-drunk husband. She’s constantly angry at them but rescuing them is what gave her days meaning. Meanwhile, Jin Jin’s brother JinMo watches so much Godfather that the line between life and his mafia fantasy blurs. He started to talk in a lower register tone, smoke cigars, spouts heroic melodramatic lines, and starts an actual crime ring. 

While Jin Jin’s mother life consists of surviving one crisis to another, her identical twin sister has a responsible albeit boring husband, A-students albeit sheltered children, and a perfect yet stifling life. Both sisters are prone to bouts of hyperbole - but one of anger, and one of joy. 

Jin Jin herself is navigating through contradictions herself - between choosing the well-traveled path of marriage or to take charge of her life, to forgive her father whose violent streaks are eclipsed by his melancholic deep connection with Jin Jin, and most intriguingly: between a man who photographs and waxes poetic about wildflowers and a man who plans his feelings with a to-do list. 

I’ve always had a soft spot for coming-of-age books but rarely find one with female protagonist, let alone from Asian culture. This book feels immensely resonating and hits a bit too close to home in some allegorical place. Life is indeed rife with contradictions. The book started as a somewhat-satire with many scathing yet hilarious observations by Jin Jin about the contradictions. As the story progressed, I found myself caught off guard by how profound and achingly true it is - that “what makes us grow is not happiness, but the unhappiness we desperately try to avoid”.

Thank you @dialimm_ for gifting this incredible read. Def in my top books this year so far 💙

bali you have been swell. 
.
came for #IrwanClaudia , stayed for the memories ✨🌅
May, she will stay. and indeed May lingers.

listened to BTS since Dope era, became Army since BE era, [redacted] in Indigo era, and finally went to a concert in D-Day era. happy 10th anniversary BTS and whatever-th anniversary to fellow Army - it’s always the right time 💜 see you in 2025! 
.
special thanks to @patrishsil and @reinecassandra for sharing these surreal experiences with me 🥲

#Michoolin Seoul is back with must visits places if you also love music & books. Had such a fun time walking around Seoul (and it’s such a big city?) and exploring these places while spring was in the air 💙 Do check out previous posts for art museum and galleries list. 
.

1. Dae-Oh Bookstore - one of the oldest bookstores in Seoul that has also risen to fame due to their famous visitors and appearances in multiple K-dramas. The owner is a very kind & friendly auntie, and the place is indeed a vibe. It’s now transformed into a cafe where you can chill and read the books on display. I cannot read Hangul so I spent my time there doodling and watching people that walk by the window display. Doodling in coffee shops is the best (and it’s so hard to do in SG hehehe) so I definitely see this place becoming one of my fav weekend hangs if I live in Seoul.
.
2. Chungwoon Literature Library - from all the places i visited during the trip, this one takes the cake as the main highlight. Such a quiet and peaceful place, surrounded by nature. I got there quite early in the morning and there was only one other visitor. I sat by the window and drew on my sketchbook while enjoying the cool spring breeze, the sound of birds chirping and water trickling from the fountain. (However the other visitor then closed the window cause the wind was getting too cold. Can’t he see that I was romanticizing my lyfe lol. let me be, pls)
.
3. Dope Records - a haven and treasure trove for audiophiles or anyone who loves music! Extensive selection of cassette, CD, and vinyls - i can spend hours crate-digging here but vinyl ain’t cheap and i’m not made of money lol. Erawise, they have massive selection of international music from the 90s - early 2000s and retro Korean music (trot and ballad). Beside Epik High’s Sleepless In record, I also managed to find Ryuichi Sakamoto’s Music For Film record that’s been on my wishlist but can never find in SG. Sidenote: they do have some selection of Japanese Citypop (one of my fav genres too) but the price is a bit more steep compared to in SG. So if you want to collect Japanese Citypop records - buy ‘em in SG.. or Tokyo lol. (continued in comment)

#Michoolin Seoul City Guide continues with everyone’s fav topic: FOOD 🔥 the funny thing is i love eating and i like Korean food, but somehow my Seoul trips ended up to revolve more around visiting museums and parks lol…hashtag aesthetics. Also i wasn’t too committed on visiting the ~famous must visit restaurants. That said, these are the 10 best things i ate during the spring trip: 
.
1. Mapook beef soup, Mapo-gu : order “한우차돌탕 / hanwoo chadoltang” and thank me later! I ate this on a rainy morning and tho the beef soup doesn’t look like much, but the broth is so flavorful and that Hanwoo beef just melts like butter. Thank you @dialimm_ for the reco! 
.
2. Pro Ganjang Gejang, Sinsa-dong : the ~viral dish that got the whole internet curious:  soy-marinated crab - including me! Thank you @jungjoo_me for making my crab dream came true and for the delightful team dinner lol. 
.
3. 장사랑, Sinsa-dong : when @yasmin.abdullah recommended this place, i was like: “really? pancake made of meat?” - but after i tried it: “REALLY! Pancake made of meat!!”
.
4. Baeknyeon Tojong Samgyaetang, Mapo-gu: this one is a bit of a tourist spot and i didn’t get to compare it to the famous Tosokchon Samgyetang (the line was too long), but it tasted really good on a rainy cold night.
.
5. 육연타 마포, Mapo-gu: a neighbourhood place i chanced upon my park stroll. I usually find Japanese tonkatsu a bit too rich but the Korean version is juicier - and with fresh soba on the side, it feels like the perfect spring dish! 
.
6. 60gye Chicken: recommended by Jeon Jungkook via @patrishsil lol (friends issit?). The chicken is so crispy and that corn mayo dip is a game changer. 
.

[Continued in Comment]

So I will try, I will wait patiently for July
Or move to somewhere with a clearer sky
When I do, life will be yellow
I won't sink into the blue
.
alternative title:
Q: So how many D-Day concerts you went to in June?
A: …yes.
first painting in a while. half rusty, half muscle memory. and the soundtrack.
Away We Gogh. a day in the sun amidst all the blues.
paris day 1. excited to see all the museums & paintings i’ve only read in art books all these years. this is, like, my coachella.

"illusion of an endless whole, of a wave with no horizon and no shore" - Claude Monet, on his monumental Water Lilies at Musee de L’Orangerie. the dimension of the paintings surrounds, or rather envelopes, their viewers across nearly one hundred linear meter - in two rooms shaped like double ellipse, forming the symbol of infinity ♾️

everyone’s taking photo at the louvre, even the sculptures.
.
a bit too frazzled after the louvre experience. decided to take a golden hour film camera stroll and was met with the most Turner-ian sunset 💙

♾️ / ♾️ 
.
bday at city of light with @itsmabellim

one of lyfe bucket list checked off: to see Monet’s Impressions, Sunrise with my own eyes - ie: the painting that “created” Impressionism. also saw Picasso’s Blue Period painting and his rendition of Manet’s Luncheon On The Grass (apparently beside Velasquez’s Las Meninas, this is another painting that Picasso was “obsessed” about and spent years to re-interpret), engravings by Degas and Fantin Latour - among others, and met Fontaine’s crow and fox. the perfect thing to do on a rainy afternoon in Paris.
.
“The pain passes but the beauty remains” - Renoir

Pinault and Pompidou, with a side of Bacon.
.
after days of classics, decided to do a modern art day by visiting Bourse de Commerce/the Pinault Collection and the iconic Centre Pompidou. aside from first time seeing a Francis Bacon triptych (portrait of George Dyer), my fav artworks are the talking mouse (Ratatouille is that you??*) /…/…/… , 2019 by Ryan Gander; The Colors of Grey by Thu Van Tran - the description give me goosebumps. history is ambiguous indeed. 
.
also made a stop at legendary stores Deyrolle (one of Wes Anderson’s fav places haha) and Senelier (art store that supplies artists Degas, Cezzane, Picasso, and Hockney - among others).
. 
.

* i know lah the mouse’s name is actually Remy, not Ratatouille.

took a train to Brussel to catch Jean Jullien’s - my favorite illustrator of all thyme - biggest exhibition in Europe. back in November ‘22, i also had a chance to catch his exhibition in Seoul, which covers his work in all encompassing medium - from product design to animation. But the exhibition in Seoul only included very few paintings and I wished there are more. Fast forward to August 2023 and this exhibition in Brussel actually focuses on his paintings. It’s deeply inspiring especially reading all his narrative about the difference between his process and intent while creating doodles of daily life versus when painting. As y’all know, I also ~dabbled in both but haven’t been able to do much of either in the last few years. This exhibition and the trip in general really inspired me to pick up the paint brush or the pen again. it really is a gift and a privilege to tell our story through art 💙

another highlight of Brussel daytrip: visit to home of René Magritte, Belgian surrealist painter and one of my favorite artists. visited the Museé Magritte - which holds the biggest collection of his work in the world, as well as his literal home 🏠 it’s so fascinating to see how much of his ‘home’ is captured in his paintings - a lot of elements in the ‘dream landscape’ shown in his paintings are actually elements from his house - the crown molding, the narrow stairway, the double doorframe - as well as the blue clear sky of Brussel ☁️ and of course: the (not) pipe 💙 other than that, i also realize how much important words are in the work of Magritte - both the words he wrote in the paintings (Ceci n’est pas une pipe), but more importantly the title of his paintings which will give us new perspective and context to ‘decipher’ his otherwise-esoteric visuals. on that note, my favorite painting is the second photo in this slide - titled “The Unexpected Answer”.

wearing kebaya in stockholm today to celebrate indonesia’s independence day and our rich & beautiful culture. merdeka.
.
📸 by @belletngo and @dialimm_ 🫶🏻

of all the places i’d like to spend my birthday at this year, Giverny is too fantastical to even be on the wish list. it’s the place i’ve read about for years in art books and of course saw in Claude Monet’s many paintings of the waterlily pond and the japanese bridge in his house’s ‘backyard’. deeply grateful to God that i get to spend my birthday in this beautiful place - with amazing weather too (after non-stop torrential rain in the past week, according to the tour guide).
.
just like how giverny reflects its designer and creator, my wish is that with every year my life becomes a clearer reflection of The One who designs and creates it.

is it me or is it getting ~ Calder in here?
.
plein air drawing with/of Alexander Calder’s Little Janey Waney in the marvellous, marvellous sculpture garden of Lousiana Museum of Modern Art. easily became one of my fav museums in this globe.

one highlight from copenhagen is definitely Louisiana Museum of Modern Art - i came mainly for the Giacometti wing and the sculpture garden filled with works from Calder,  Serra, and Miro. turns out the two special exhibitions really blew me away. “Black Light” - retrospective of Georgian painter Niko Pirosmani whose singularity is likened to that of Edward Hopper and Georgia O’Keefe. His painting style reminds me of folk art and a bit of outsider art, in their naïveté and obscurity. The other work that became very memorable to me is video installation by Scandinavian artist Ragnar Kjartansson and none other than one of my favorite bands of all time - The National 😭 “A Lot of Sorrow” is a recording of the band’s 6 hours live performance of their song “Sorrow” in front of audience at MoMa. Throughout the performance, you can see how the melody, the lyrics, and the energy in the room shifted and in a way become a performer on its own. so beautiful and making a mental note that someday i’ll come back to this museum.

celebrating one year in @Spotify ✨ swipe to see the First Day At Work taken exactly a year ago. excited as i was back then, i was also worried about so many things - starting in a new role, in a new company, in a new industry, and working with so many new people. there were a thousand What Ifs in my head. flash forward a year later (and indeed it feels that time moved in warped speed) and so many have happened: new friendships, new ideas, new learnings, and new opportunities (incl opportunity to meet my fav artist lol). i still have a lot of What If’s but most of them excite me instead. grateful for day one, grateful for today - and everything that has happened in between.

there’s certainly a sense of calm and melancholy that subdued you in every museums in copenhagen, almost the polar opposite of paris’ museums vibrant and bustling (albeit a bit overwhelming) energy. Glyptoteket is a place i discovered through Instagram last year - it looks so magical on the videos i saw, but then i felt crestfallen when i found out it was all the way in copenhagen - a place i thought i’d never visit. but there i was - marvelling at the wonderful architecture, as well as the beautifully curated collection - most of the paintings ( largely by Swedish and French artist) also have that “stillness in the air” feeling - which again, contrasts the elusive & ephemeral French Impressionism i’ve been immersing into the week before. all in all, still can’t believe i got to visit this place. never say never, i guess 💫

summer in copenhagen turned out to be very idyllic. besides the museums, i spent a lot of time at the botanic gardens - drawing (perfect spot for plein air), reading (Harrow by Joy Williams), sleeping under a tree (first world activity 😂 my fight or flight instinct constantly kept me on alert, but everyone in the park minded their own business except for the ducks), eating Danish pastry in Denmark itself (it was SO good - crumbly and light), thrifting (got this coolest oversized wool blazer), and all around just chilling. I read that Copenhagen was among the top cities in the world for ‘work-life balance’ and the ‘happiness’ index. i personally find those two terms to be very ambiguous, but after 5 days in copenhagen - and seeing how many people were lying down on the grass around me on a Monday afternoon - i think i get it. copenhagen, you’re alright.
plein air drawing at copenhagen botanical garden 🦆
audition tape to become “Tomato Girl” 🍅 what i noticed in Paris is that people dress so chic yet understated & personal, unlike the glitzy Parisian Style hashtag that all look the same lol.

merry-go-round of lyfe indeed. 
.
.
from string quartet in a candlelit 150 year old concert hall…to seeing Joe Hisaishi himself conducting a full orchestra 🥲🎻tagging front row buddy @dewiyusup
paris you’re alright 💙

when i just joined Spotify i heard that all new joiners go to IntroDays in Stockholm headquarter to get to hear about the company’s history, culture, and vision from the co-founders + c-suite themselves, and i was like “….really?”. turns out: really!
.
.
really grateful for fun & inspiring thymes at IntroDays and exploring STO together - and sharing all the good food - with the awesome peeps of Team APAC (the best team - my biased opinion) 🥳🙌🏻 swipe til the end to see my botched attempt to take group pic with our Chief HR Officer who bartended on the big party 😆 felt like a great way to ‘bookmark’ my first year in Spotify too - some colleagues said they can’t believe i’ve just been a bandmember for a year (why??) but i honestly feel like time flew by so fast. it’s a year of being outside the comfort zone in every way possible - and how fun it has been! here’s to keep learning, unlearning, and growing. 
.
PS: after IntroDays come…IntrovertDays
painting giverny while in copenhagen. some summer days felt like a dream.

emily in pasir ris.
.
i don’t care much about what ernest hemingway had to say about a lot of things, but paris is indeed a moveable feast 💙

film shots from spring in seoul, autumn in tokyo, summer in bali. it makes zero sense but feels like my camera travels more than i do. maybe because it captured the moment & the place as it was, while my mind tend to wander elsewhere. 
.
long time no #choonica35mm 📸 maybe the goal is not to be better at photography, but to be better at being present. 
idk.

show me the monet 🪷 encounters with claude throughout the years:
1. At the monumental Water Lilies cycle - Musee de L’Orangerie. Monet’s biggest and most ambitious water lilies paintings. Paris, 2023
2. painting Giverny at Copenhagen Botanical Garden, 2023
3. @real_choochoo met Monet in Singapore National Gallery, 2018
4. Choo Choo pondering on art and what it does for/to us, 2018
5. Monet at Lee Kun-hee Collection exhibition, MMCA Gwacheon, 2023
6. Drawing Monet while processing an emotional breakdown lol. Onion Cafe - Anguk, 2022
7. Monet at National Museum of Western Art, Tokyo, 2022
8. My drawing to commemorate first time seeing Monet painting in real lyfe in Tokyo, 2015
9. After all these years, laid eyes on Impression, Sunrise - the painting that pretty much gave birth to Impressionism. Musee Monet Marmottan, 2023
10. Standing at THE Japanese bridge over THE waterlilies pond at THE actual estate of Claude Monet himself, Giverny. Normandy, 2023
.
if i ever crack the code on how to like something without being obsessed about it, i’ll let you know.

another lyfe bucketlist ticked off: seeing Vilhelm Hammershøi paintings in his hometown Copenhagen. Hammershøi, one of my favorite painters of all time, was a celebrated Danish painter known for his meditative interiors and landscapes. he often used muted toned and shown figures (often female) from the back - as if turning away from glare of viewers. his painting always feels serene - and i gotta say that overall athmosphere of Copenhagen’s Staten Museum for Kunst was also very subdued and calming. i wasn’t very well-versed in Danish art, but can’t help to notice there’s a sense of stillness in most of the paintings and it’s very alluring ☁️

October 5th, 2023 marks the fourth year of starting a new chapter of lyfe in Singapore. there are countless ups and downs in these years. as the photo collage shows, my weight has gone up and down lol. and the year where i look physically the fittest (2020), was also the year where i struggled a lot mentally, amidst isolation and uncertainty during pandemic. many success, but also many losses (or maybe: lessons). there also things that have happened in the last 4 years - and especially in the most recent year - that i could’ve never imagined - breakthroughs and miracles. yet, there are many dreams and hopes that i still wait for to this day. it’s easy to think “four year is a long time, how can not i figure it out already?” and get ridden with anxiety and maybe a bit of self pity. but the answer is simple - God is not done with me. His ways are miles above mine and His plan and purpose is way beyond my own self. I am grateful for all the days God has carried me through and hopeful for the ones ahead. may good days become a reminder that God is good, and bad days PROOF that He is good. 
.
“The steadfast love of the LORD never ceases; his mercies never come to an end; they are new every morning; great is your faithfulness. “ - Lamentations 3:22-23

history is written by winners - therefore maybe historical fiction exists so that we may know the truth. The Buddha in The Attic is the second Julie Otsuka book I’ve read and her most critically-acclaimed work to date. It chronicles the journey of a group of Japanese young women who sailed the ocean into ‘the land of free’ to meet the men who will take their hand in marriage and start a new life there. I won’t divulge much about the book plot here - I went into it blind (ie: having no idea what the book is about) and honestly it was the best way to read this. Every chapter will present to you a surprise, a tragedy, and a heartbreak. It’s deeply moving while at the same time shedding a light to a part of American history that was mostly kept in the dark.
.

last year, I ‘discovered’ Julie Otsuka’s work through The Swimmers - her most recent work that was chosen & discussed in Sorry I’m booked - a bookclub that I participated in. It was an magnificent book and I was particularly captivated by the first part of the book, written from the point of view of a collective “we” that is both singular and numerous, familiar yet foreign.  To my delight, the entirety of The Buddha in The Attic is written from a collective “we” perspective as well - and I feel Otsuka’s beautiful prose really really shine. 
One of the best books I’ve ever read - and the fact that I purchased it at legendary bookstore Shakespeare & Company and read it (in two sittings) while sitting on Parisian park bench definitely made this book immensely memorable for me. 
.
if you’re inclined, find my review on The Swimmers and other books I’ve enjoyed in #biblichootheque 💫

Kim Beom - How To Become A Rock. splendid exhibition and i think i discovered a new favorite artist. Kim Beom’s work is bitingly funny and unassumingly profound - it will put a smile on your face while leaving you plenty to ponder about. it’s clever without that air of esoteric pomposity that some conceptual art tend to have lol. My absolute artwork is “Objects being taught they are nothing but tools” - where households object sat in a classroom setting and the professor lectured them about the history of human - tools - and products. the more i watch the video, the more i’m convinced that the artwork is a satirical nod to consumerism or even capitalism. while “tool using” ability was once what marks advancement of humanity (Homo habilis - the “handy man”), maybe modern day capitalism in turn made human now mere tools
to those who wield power and generate profits?
.
other faves: “a rock that was taught it’s a bird” and “an iron in the farm of a radio, a kettle in the form of an iron, and a radio in the form of a kettle”

so grateful i get a chance to again visit one of my favorite museums in this planet - Whanki Museum. this time around, the exhibition focuses on the artist’s most iconic era: the dots paintings (1968-1974, when the artist passed away). just like last time - Kim Whanki’s big scale, meditative, and mostly monochromatic paintings captivated me - but this time, through the descriptions and exhibition booklet, i was able to learn more about the dot paintings era.

.
“the title of a painting is something that is named by the viewer. i paint without thinking of anything. if i do think of something, it is about friends mostly who passed away or even i don’t know whether alive or not. i paint with sadness but i hope my work will be cheerful“. Kim Whanki struck me as someone who chronicled the passage of time, both the significance and insignificance of a single day - through his numerous daily journals, his many letters to home during his stay in New York, through the title of his paintings - mostly marking the completion date of the painting, and perhaps most enigmatically through the dots in his paintings, which he painted with Seoul in mind and “a million other things”. 
.
photographs inside the two main buildings / exhibitions are not allowed - but i noted down the titles and quotes that made a mark. also, i was’t lucky enough to meet the museum mascot: Mumio, the cat that lives in the museum’s front yard. but met an excited shiba and a gang of cats who look like they meant trouble.
.
but When, in What Form, Shall We Meet Again?

seems that my travel schedule somehow syncs with exhibition schedule of my fav illustrator: Jean Jullien. lol how did this happen. after catching Then, There - his large retrospective in DDP Seoul last year, and then his painting exhibition Studiolo in Mima Museum Brussels earlier this year, today I managed to visit Les Amis - Jean Jullien group exhibition with his friends and brother : Yann Le Bec, Gwendal Le Bec, and Nico Jullien. I really dig Nico Jullien’s wooden animal sculpture especially the bird on the first photo - titled Oops. I also really enjoyed Yann Le Bec’s lively portrayal of Paris and Montmatre and Gwendal Le Bec’s vibrant flowers and landscape. it’s pretty cool to be friends with fellow artists and to do exhibitions together - though each artist has a different style and selection of subject matter, the works displayed in this exhibition somehow have a similar vibrant color palette and captured a sense of camaraderie. a shot of summer sunlight in the midst of a gloomy autumn day. 
.
also: somehow the exhibition makes me miss @ladiesdrawingclub.jkt and my illustrator fwends in jakarta. hope you’re all well 💙
on daze like these 🍂

“In this time anyone can take a picture anytime, anywhere, and easily, the sense of selecting one from tons of images and the touch that adds to it is what Mok’s photography is all about.” - Soft/Hard : Mok Jungwook solo show. 
.
really enjoyed this photography exhibition - both . the gas stations and signages remind me of Ed Ruscha and Stephen Shore, and the manifesto reminds me of William Eggleston - but of course, the images uniquely seen through Mok Jungwook’s lens and perspective. 
.
PS: there’s so many cool and diverse exhibitions in seoul. i will try harder to find art exhibitions in singapore too.

autumn leaves. it leaves a lush carpet of yellow and orange, and its yours to decide which direction you want to step towards (the right one or the one left). it leaves a promise of warm daylights and gradient sunsets though you know cold, grey days are imminent - and you realize why people hope. it leaves you wondering why endings always feel certain while beginnings ever uncertain, when they are both the same node in this path. it leaves you wondering what if.

spring and autumn in seoul
1. namsan blossoms and namsan foliage
2. when petals fall and when leaves fall
3. calder and calder. the caldest.
4. whanki and whanki. always whanki. 
5. fav painter and fav illustrator (claude monet and jean jullien. also: french and french)
6. pink and orange
7. lee ufan and kim beom
8. pablo picasso’s owl and nico jullien’s owl
9. macallan + vinyl and balvenie + vinyl.
10. hotteok and hotteok (and still not enough)
.
may we find what we love and what we love find us 💫 until next time, seoul.

t’was a good day. Chang Ucchin retrospective at MMCA Deoksugung. learned a lot about this renowned Korean painter and the principles behind his art - which was inspired a lot by Buddhism teachings. i also noticed that that many preeminent Korean painters have similar ‘naive’ childlike style, including Lee Jung Seop whose retrospectives i managed to visit during my April trip. makes me think a lot about how artists express our identity - our belief and our nationality - through art.
.
thinking to write something abt Indonesian art and Korean art. our independence day are only two days apart, and i see so much parallels and compelling juxtaposition between Indonesian art and Korean art 🤯 brb doing more research
the writings/right things on the wall.

other than Monet, the artist whose work/exhibitions i’ve seen the most is Jean Jullien. Seoul, November 2023 - Brussels, August 2023 - Seoul, November 2022. always so inspiring to see his work - prolific and profound while playful at the same time. wishing one day to get a chance to work together as illustrator. hey one can dream, right.

#biblichootheque book review is back with this crime-thriller i bought at incheon airport book store and read during my flight back. definitely a page-turner and somewhat a classic Who Dunnit, as the narrative was told from the point of view of the different suspects and witnesses of the case - and each of them distorts the truth by omitting or adding critical details from their retelling. decidedly unsentimental, this book tells us a chain effect of a tragedy that rippled through families and decades - and it will make you realize that the real tragedy is life goes on anyway. there’s something cold and clinical about how the story was told, and i think it adds more to the sadness of the story. 
.
my only critique for the book is.. i wish there are more chapters. the characters are so evocative that i wouldn’t mind reading more about them.

Suki Seokyeong Kang, Kim Beom, Anish Kapoor, and Alexander Calder. another visit to one of my fav modern art museums. i like everything in this museum even the overpriced coffee shop and the hidden toilets lol.

#biblichootheque book review of the first book i completed in 2024 - although i started reading it months ago. This book is the third Julie Otsuka book I’ve read and similar to the other two novels, it feels deeply personal as Otsuka writes about the life of Japanese immigrants in America. “When the Emperor Was Divine” particularly tells the story of a Japanese American family whose life changed overnight when they were sent to the Japanese internment camp in America during the second World War. It’s gut-wrenching and poignant - with vivid and somewhat poetic details described so eloquently. Upon reading more about the author’s background, I found out that she is trained as a painter - which explains why the prose is always so “lush” and evocative, even when describing the most mundane things. I also learned that although she did not live through the Japanese internment period, her mother, uncle, and two grandparents did, which gives Otsuka a personal perspective on the matter. More than a beautiful work of literature, this book (and her later work “The Buddha in the Attic”) sheds a light on a part of American history that is rarely talked about but somehow seem to be interwoven throughout the nation’s journey: the price that has to be paid for so-called freedom. 
.
here’s to reading more books in 2024 - books that enrich our inner world as well as our outlook into this world 💫

it is well.  
✏️ @real_choochoo
